annotation.TEXT: Thankfully, there's no auto-scrolling sections in the next stage. With that being said however, Wily 2 is no slouch either. It's filled with underwater sections, tight precision jumps, timed blocks, conveyor belts, and fans. The combinations with all these gimmicks can make for a pretty hectic experience, to say the least. In addition, this stage also features a few cameos of Robot Masters from other fan-games (most of which were cancelled). I'm not exactly familiar with all of them, but I'll try to name off the ones I at least recognize to some extent.
Ocean Man (MM Plus)

Just a forewarning at this point: For those of you that are a bit sensitive to full-screen effects (or if you don't like having your eyes assaulted), I suggest you either skip to 3:08 or look away from the screen for a few seconds after I jump down this next pit.

On hindsight, the constant explosions might not seem that bad on the recording. When you're actually in-game however, it's a much different story. It also doesn't help that it's essentially the lead-off to another auto-scrolling section, but this time with an even higher threat of instant death.
Boost Man (MM: Time Tangent)

With everything else out of the picture, it's time to take on Wily's fortress. Now then...up until this point, I would honestly rank this game's difficulty level as somewhat average in most regards (barring a few exceptions in certain stages). Here's where all of that goes sailing right out of the window.
Kind of like what almost happened right there. Even though most of the shots despawn if you fire it near the top of the screen, a few of them can still veer off and potentially kill you.

It's also worth mentioning that if you die anywhere in this segment, you get sent all the way back to the start of the Clamp-Dozer section. This basically means you need to get through both of these auto-scrolling sections in one clean run, and only then will you be able to get to the other checkpoint of this level.

Somewhat taking the role of "Giant Space Flea from Nowhere" is the Clamp-Dozer. You can't damage him in any way, essentially making this a survival auto-scrolling section. The Clamp-Dozer itself has three attacks that repeat in a set pattern: It'll launch its claw straight-forward, shoot an exploding ball aimed slightly ahead of where you're currently standing, and then fire a missile that locks onto your horizontal location.

A slight oddity here: Apparently your weapons can't pass through this door after it's been knocked down (or at least, the Illusion Blast can't). I have no idea why this is, but it certainly limits your options for dealing with the first seal enemy.
Magpulse Man - Outdated Design (Mega Man F)
Cloak Man (Mega Man SS)

Finally, we come to the rematch with Bass...and he's actually easier than he was in the first fight. Bass jumps much higher than he did before, and the level ground makes avoiding his attacks far more manageable. He does have a few new attacks, along with adding hazards to the environment as the fight goes along, but all of them are easy enough to avoid (with the possible exception of his new Saber-move, which comes out pretty quick).

Granted, most of them die in one hit...but there's one in particular that doesn't. You'd seriously have to know this enemy is here before-hand to even have a chance at getting rid of it (and even then, unless you spam the hell out of Illusion Blast, there's still a strong chance you'll get hit by it and run into the spikes).

And now we move on to Wily 3...let me tell you something about Wily 3: This stage can go straight to hell. It's right up there with Metal Man's stage from Eons of Dreams 2 in terms of how frustrating it is. If you don't have prior knowledge of anything on this stage before going into it, be prepared to die several times over.

The second section of this stage isn't much better. It all focuses on frustrating platforming elements combined with puzzles, most of which involve using the Scorch Flame (which you can also screw yourself over with if you use it at the wrong time).
Dog Man (MM Mania)

Note: When you get to this part, make sure you immediately switch weapons after burning the top two ice blocks. If you don't, the lingering aura from the Scorch Flame can actually destroy the ice blocks that are supposed to serve as a platform, which will then dump you into the spikes below.

CWU-01P2 is the boss for this stage - going off of aspects from the same one in the original MM1 (along with another particular boss from the franchise). It has three phases, though thankfully only retains a single healthbar. Even still, this fight can be a bit tiresome if you're not planning on using its weakness. The main reason for this is its bubble-shield, which will slowly regenerate over time. Thankfully it ditches this thing for its third phase, but you still need to be pretty quick about damaging it otherwise.

Suddenly, we get to fight Quint. He has a few more attacks when compared to his original version, though he's still pretty easy to deal with. The only reason I messed up this fight a bit is because the Ballade Missile seems to enjoy going in any direction other than straight-forward at times. In turn, this could force you to get up close to Quint for this fight (which I wouldn't really recommend, given how fast some of his attacks come out).

Also, make absolutely sure to time your jumps carefully when doing this. The ice blocks don't respawn if you leave the screen. If you accidentally destroy some of the required block placements, your only option is to kill yourself on some spikes just to have another shot at these damned sections.

What really gets to me however is that you can actually destroy the platforms, which can both screw you over and prevent you from attacking the Dragon (charged shots don't pierce through the blocks). The Dragon itself is incredibly weak in the HP department, but its weakness happens to be the Frigid Frost - a weapon that spawns a bunch of spread shots that fly off in random directions, which can easily fall back down and destroy the only things allowing you to survive in this fight.
Shark Man (MM3 DOS)

Keeping track of this attack pattern makes this section a bit easier, but it can still be pretty frustrating if you happen to get knocked back in a bad spot. If you get dragged into the Clamp-Dozer's sprite, you're basically dead (contact with him doesn't instantly kill you, but the amount of recoil and low invincibility time will guarantee that you'll get stun-locked with no way to escape).

Now that we've finally gotten off of Dr. Wily's Wild Ride, it's time to fight an equally terrible mini-boss. There are so many things wrong with this fight that I'm honestly surprised no one petitioned to remove it from the game: First off, your jump flow is completely changed during this battle. I get that it's an auto-scrolling segment, but the shift from having an ultra-stiff jump to a suddenly weird, forced, floaty jump is so jarring that it throws the whole thing off.

Warning: When you're on the lower section of this room, DO NOT use the Scorch Flame while standing. You need to jump and use it, otherwise it will destroy the ice blocks resting on the spikes, and in turn, forcing you to kill yourself because there's no way to progress.

The lead singer of a punk metal band (rather fitting, given the obvious). The aptly named "Mega Man Killer" here is actually pretty easy compared to the stage, even if you're facing his more difficult form. His attacks actually change depending on whether or not you beat the Mega Man Killers earlier in the game. In either case however, his attacks are actually rather simple to avoid (with the exception of the one he gets from Enker, which comes out way too fast for its own good).

Wily 1 starts off simple enough, though there are a few things that can easily throw you off: The constantly respawning Docrons (or "Wilycarts") in particular can be annoying, as well as the seal enemies that show up out of nowhere to lob fast moving projectiles at you.
And by their powers combined, they create...
Key Man? (MM: Wanted - I can't really tell, since the conveyor wheel is obscuring him)
Blade Man (MM DOS)

First off, we start on a rail section akin to the one from Primal Man's stage. There's enemies littered everywhere, but unlike Primal Man's stage, a majority of these are placed in downright evil locations rather than mostly cluttering the screen. A few of them show up right in front of spikes as well, which can easily lead to an instant death if you happen to get hit by them (remember: MM1 spike rules).
